awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Algorithms for Tensor-Based Modeling of Large Scale Structured Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to develop efficient algorithms for big data applications by exploiting its rich structure. Big data often contains higher-dimensional arrays. One dimensional arrays are vectors and two dimensional arrays are matrices. Arrays of dimension three or more are called tensors and have a complex structure. Some of the challenges that the research team will address are noise removal, recovery of missing data by inference and data size reduction by distilling relevant information. The resulting methods will be applied to early detection of sepsis, which contributes to the death of 200,000 people in the United States every year.

Most algorithms for low rank structured tensors are based on the Canonical Polyadic decomposition (also known as CP, Parafac or Candecomp). These algorithms may converge slowly, are numerically unstable and are difficult to scale to big data. The theoretical framework for tensor decompositions that is used is based on an algebraic graphical calculus that utilizes colored Brauer diagrams to obtain explicit formulas. The graphical calculus will also be used to give accurate estimates for the computational and memory complexity of these algorithms. The investigators will design efficient, numerically stable and computationally feasible algorithms for crucial tensor operations that are widely applicable to big data applications. Specifically, the project isexpected to create fast, scalable and reliable algorithms for tensor analysis, and apply them to crucial big data tasks including noise removal, dimension reduction, imputation of missing data and classification in a variety of applications with structured data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Merit: This project focused on developing algebraic methods for computations with tensor data. In particular, we developed a system of data processing using CP decomposition as a feature reduction method of tensor data. We have used and tested this process on real-world ECG datasets, such as the publicly available PTB dataset and the University of Michigan retrospective dataset, to predict different health-related outcomes using features formatted as a tensor. Models trained using signal-derived tensor features demonstrate some distinct advantages. For example, the ability to use multimodal data to predict an increase in qSOFA score using continuous arterial line and ECG. The Kempf-Ness model allows using tensors themselves as input, rather than a vectorization of tensors. Both using CP decomposition as a method of feature reduction and the Kempf-Ness models allow for tensorial structural information to be included in the model training process. The advantage of using signal data in the hospital setting is that ECG data collection is noninvasive, routine in the intensive care unit (ICU) and collected continuously. Unlike electronic health record (EHR) data, which is collected at different intervals depending on the feature (for example, hourly for fluid output, every 15 minutes for heart rate, or sporadically for other measures). Being able to extract informative features from ECG signal data for different conditions, such as heart conditions in the PTB data, or increase in qSOFA for the University of Michigan retrospective data, contributes to development of clinical decision support systems that can be used in the ICU.

 

Broader Impact: Our research endeavors provide new insights into the use of tensor structures in the domain of machine learning. This award aided investigations into different aspects of tensor analysis, including approximation of the spectral norm, tensor amplification, tensor decomposition, tensor-based dimension reduction, noise level estimation, tensor completion, and classification problems. By studying each of these different aspects both in a mathematical context as well as applications in healthcare, we make the usage of tensors more accessible to future researchers in the medical domain. This award supported both graduate and post-doctoral researchers, fostering their growth into more seasoned research professionals, and continued the ongoing advancement of clinical decision support systems. 


 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2023
Modified by: Kayvan Najarian
